Background:
Nowadays, a growing number of TV dramas have been adapted from classic works of the same title. Of course, there is nothing wrong with this. But should the original ones be totally changed just for catching audiences' eyes? A recent case concerns Jin Yong's famous Kongfu novel, The Smiling Proud Wanderer(Xiao ao jiang hu), which has been adapted again for the screen by FAMOUS scriptwriter, Mr. Yu. With its subversion of the characters and shocking plot, it became a massive hit. Those within film and TV circles criticize him for he spoils the rules of this field while some youngsters, especially those born after 1995, argue that but for the TV drama they would not know this book.

话题：

Topic:
Have you ever seen this new TV drama? What do you think of it? Are you shocked by it? Or do you just think that is no ground for blame? Write whatever you want to say.

范例1：

Actually, I felt very angry at this remake drama immediately I saw its trailer. No words could describe my disappointment and annoyance. It totally did ruin the characters I like. In my view, it is not innovation, but an eye-catching publicity stunt. Definitely, under market economy system, money talks and audience ratings mean a lot to TV stations and media firms. But should they sacrifice their responsibilities just for pursuit of interests? Is the rise in ratings well worth the decline of quality? And what I wonder most is the place where they will draw the bottom line. Entering the visual communication ages, the attention becomes the important and economic resources. Maybe closing my eyes to many things is my best silent boycott. I don’t worry much about the classic, because the reason why the classic can be classic is that they will never fade with the passing of time.

范例2：

I haven’t seen it yet. For me, adapted movies offer a different way to savor the books. They can satisfy our desire to see characters come into life. The boundless landscape and charming Mr. Darcy in the movie Pride and Prejudice are truly arresting. Or they might kill our romance. I found the book Hunger Games quite fun and gripping but my fantasy was strangled by the adapted movie. As for the movies that are just made for entertainment, I see most of them a flop. Pilgrimage to the West (Xi you ji) has been adapted into many wild versions. I shudder to think that Sun Wukong would want to be loved by a woman. I’d rather fancy the book as one of trust, loyalty and persistence.

歌曲介绍：

Moonlight Shadow 《月光之影》　据说，这首1983年问世的曲子原是为纪念甲壳虫乐队（The Beatles）被枪杀的主唱约翰·列侬（John Lennon）而作。 1980年12月8日，马克·查普曼伪装成一个歌迷，在列侬的公寓旁边徘徊了很久。那天晚上，当列侬从录音棚返回家中的时候，查普曼请列侬在他的签字本上签名。当时他内心曾进行过激烈的斗争，但最后仍然举起手枪朝着列侬的后背连开了5枪。 和Moonlight Shadow中所写的“He was shot six times by a man on the run”类似。 但看了原版的MTV之后，这首歌应该和John Lennon的被刺并没有直接联系，似乎男主角死于一场决斗中，这倒象是普希金，但不知道普希金的妻子娜达丽亚会不会这样来怀念他。

这首歌的歌词曾经一直被认为是指约翰·列侬的谋杀案的，然而歌曲中的事件和列侬谋杀案并无关系。列侬是在晚11点前被射四枪，而歌曲中的时间是凌晨四点，且枪击数为六。在1995年的一次采访中，当被问及《Moonlight Shadow》是否是指代约翰·列侬谋杀案时，欧菲尔德回应道：
“并非如此……当然，当我回顾的时候，也许是吧。其实我是在他被枪杀的那个可怕的晚上到达纽约的，我住在维京唱片在佩里街的房子，那儿里事发的从达科他大厦仅有几条街的路，所以它可能深埋于我的潜意识当中了。它最初灵感来自于我喜爱的电影——托尼·柯蒂斯主演的《胡迪尼》，这是通过灵媒联络死去的胡迪尼……歌曲原来的影响本该如此，而这其他影响却是我未曾想到的。”
——迈克·欧菲尔德，加雷斯·兰德尔采访迈克·欧菲尔德

背景介绍：

Nowadays in China, single people are literary running with scissors. I mean like "leftover women and men"? Come on! They shot single people, don't they? (ww) The truth is, probably all your single friends would tell you the same story

—— I don't wanna be somebody's crush, I want people to love the real me.
We Accept The Love We Think We Deserve.
We Want All Or Nothing.

话题：

If you are single, why do you choose to be single?
Or did you even choose?
If you are not, have you found true love yet?
What is true love to you?

范例1：

Love is a coincidence: we happen to admire each other at the same time. Most of us may have overlooked the importance of simultaneity. It is quite likely and in fact frequently seen in reallife that potential couples who have had enough love between them, but sadly at different times separately, end up in failure. You can hardly tell whether it is true love or not.
Humans are not created in pairs. You may spend your whole life without finding one such "destined" other half. This is not what we can control. The only thing you can do is to take good care of the one who is always beside you.

范例2：

Although I'm not a "sheng nv", I don't like the word "剩" in this term. It gives me a feeling that a girl becomes a "sheng nv" because she is no longer needed and not being loved by others. Also, the translation versions of "sheng nv" - 3S lady (single, seventies, stuck) and leftover lady - have the same meaning: they are being left, getting stuck, not able to move on or continue their lives. On the contrary, "sheng nv" can lead a wonderful life, maybe even more wonderful than girls who are dating someone. They don't have to worry about whether or not their boyfriends are hanging out with other girls, whether or not their boyfriends' ex girlfriends want to win them back. They can get rid of all these troubles and have more private time to do whatever they like.
Nowadays people tend to hold some prejudice against "sheng nv", regarding their being single as a shame. However, some girls choose to become "sheng nv" since they are serious about their lives: they want to wait for their Mr. Right (or Miss. Right XDD) regardless of how long it takes rather than see someone just for company without thinking any further.
Anyway, it is not whether being single or not that defines happiness. As long as a girl loves herself and enjoys her life, being a "sheng nv" or not is not that important.

范例3：

Just the past CNY, my parents had been rushing me to the blind dates, finally it was an article I saw from the microblog that saved me, and below was exactly what I told them:
Why a woman should marry a man? With marriage, all benefits go to men, and few or none go to women. Look, with their wives, men got free "cleaners" for their houses, free "cooks" for their daily meals, free "caregivers" for their parents; and they got babies, got someone to vent their anger once things don't go on smoothly…
And look at those poor women, with marriage they got their rest time halved, but burdens doubled, or even worse…And they are already supposed to be happy if their husbands won't throw the dirty socks and clothes to any corner of the house, and go outside to create some heartbreaking "affairs" for women to suffer…
So the happiness of a woman has nothing to do with marriage…
Next time if anyone asks the question again: "Are you engaged?"
I would right away answer him: "Yes, I'm very busy with Plato."
